subject: Re: [junit] DBUnit. How to use?
msgSnippet: Hi Veny ... Yeap! But not for long, for about 10 days to be exact. ... Yes, it s a bit confusing to start using it. ... DBUnit can certainly help you here.
messageBody:
Hi Veny

> Hi all,
>
> Has anyone use DBUnit before?
Yeap! But not for long, for about 10 days to be exact.

> I've read the write up on the sourceforge site. but quite limited
> information.
Yes, it's a bit confusing to start using it.

>
> Any clear advantages that DBUnit provides?
>
> I am writing test case on class that performs database operation -
> update, select, insert, join, delete, etc. Right now, what i am doing
> is that for method that perform SELECT operation, i would first write
> some INSERT statment to insert the test data into the database and
> then call on the select method. And after that the test, i'll also
> need to clear the data. This works, but i find that quite
> troublesome. Can DBUnit provides an easier alternative to what i am
> doing? Or is there any other easier way?

DBUnit can certainly help you here. What you do when using the DBUnit is
this:
you write (or extract) a XML file with your test data, and then there is a
couple of ways that DBUnit insert this data into the database for you (you
don't have to write a INSERT statement). If you need you can use the
tearDown() to cleanup the database after.

Try following these steps:
http://www.dbunit.org/howto.html#createtest
Then you should get a better idead of how to use DBUnit.

>
> Is DBUnit tied to any database, Oracle, MySQL, etc?

No, DBUnit is pure JDBC. As long you can provide an JDBC driver it works
with your database.

>
> Thanks lots.
>
> Veny

Hope this helps, if you need more details just ask.

Alexandre Telles
